title: 106_s1247
content: The "Fair Cost of Living Adjustment for Seniors Act of 1999" may be cited as such. It aims to improve the Consumer Price Index for the elderly through a Congressionally appointed review committee. The "Fair Cost of Living Adjustment for Seniors Act of 1999" establishes the Consumer Price Index Review Committee with 15 members appointed by Senate and House leadership. The Committee includes 11 economic experts and 4 representatives of individuals aged 65 and older, serving for a specified duration. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee, established by the "Fair Cost of Living Adjustment for Seniors Act of 1999," consists of 15 members appointed by Senate and House leadership. Vacancies on the Committee are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members serve for the duration of the Committee. The Committee must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and a majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee consists of 15 members appointed by Senate and House leadership. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Committee selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. The Committee's duties include conducting a study to improve the method for determining an index for the elderly. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee, appointed by Senate and House leadership, is tasked with improving the method for determining an index for the elderly. This includes developing an accurate market basket of goods and services for the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly. The Consumer Expenditure Survey used by the Bureau of Labor Statistics will be redesigned and expanded to collect expenditure patterns representative of the total retiree population receiving old-age and survivors insurance benefits. The areas and outlets priced by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the Experimental Consumer Price Index for the Elderly will be modified to reflect this population. The Committee will study the method for determining an accurate consumer price index for individuals who receive disability, ensuring that prices collected reflect discount availability for the total retiree population. Any limitations affecting the accuracy of the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly will be addressed. The Committee will submit a report to Congress on the study conducted regarding the consumer price index for individuals receiving disability insurance benefits. The Committee has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence to fulfill its objectives. The Committee has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. The Committee members receive compensation for their services and are allowed travel expenses. The Committee members receive compensation for their services and are allowed travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Committee has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws, with the executive director's compensation set by the Chairperson. The Committee may set the compensation for the executive director and other personnel without following certain federal laws on pay rates, with a limit on the maximum pay level. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Committee without extra reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Committee can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Committee will terminate one year after its initial meeting, and there are authorized appropriations for its operations. The Bureau of Labor Statistics will establish a pilot program to test the accuracy of the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly, which reflects changes in expenses typical for retirees receiving Social Security benefits. The program will run from the report submission under section 2(b)(2) until December 2002. Additionally, an interim application of the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers will be in effect. SEC. 4. INTERIM APPLICATION OF CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FOR ALL URBAN CONSUMERS. The Commissioner of Social Security will use the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers for cost-of-living adjustments until the Official Consumer Price Index for the Elderly is implemented. SEC. 5. APPLICATION OF CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FOR THE ELDERLY. The Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics will prepare and publish the Official Consumer Price Index for the Elderly based on the recommendations in the report submitted by the Consumer Price Index Review Committee, unless a joint resolution disapproving the report is enacted. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee must submit a report within 90 days, excluding certain days when Congress is adjourned. A joint resolution introduced within this period must not have a preamble and must follow specific guidelines. The joint resolution disapproves the report of the Consumer Price Index Review Committee on the implementation of the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly. The joint resolution disapproves the report of the Consumer Price Index Review Committee on the implementation of the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly. If a resolution described in subparagraph (A) is not reported by the committee within 60 days of the report submission, the committee will be discharged from further consideration, and the resolution will be placed on the appropriate calendar. The resolution shall be considered in the same manner as a resolution under the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990. Cost-of-living computation quarters will be based on the Consumer Price Index beginning on January 1 of the calendar year after the Bureau of Labor Statistics Commissioner's report. The Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics will use the Official Consumer Price Index for the Elderly to calculate cost-of-living adjustments for old-age and survivors insurance benefits under the Social Security Act. Appropriations are authorized for the Bureau of Labor Statistics to carry out this section.
